title: Boy, 5, died after medics misdiagnosed his chronic constipation with diabetes
text:

Doctors missed opportunities to save a five-year-old boy who died after being admitted to hospital with chronic constipation, an inquest heard today.

Shay Turner eventually suffered a catastrophic brain injury and his heartbroken family had to turn off his life support machine.

His grief-stricken mum Laura Turner, 28, today claimed staff at Rotherham General Hospital were not well equipped to deal with her son's deteriorating condition and missed several telltale signs that he could be suffering from sepsis .

The youngster's inquest in Doncaster, South Yorkshire, heard he vomited every time he took a drink and had dark rings around his eyes days before his death.

But doctors misdiagnosed Shay with Type 1 diabetes and he was given an incorrect dosage of insulin in error.

(Image: SWNS)

"There appears to have been a number of errors and our family's impression is that staff were not well equipped to deal with the situation," Laura's statement read.

"I recall Shay took a turn for the worse which is when I believe the insulin started to take effect.

"I have a number of concerns about the care which was provided to Shay. I feel that sepsis was never considered as a diagnosis."

The advertising executive, who also has a nine-year-old son called Finnley, continued: "I also feel that time was wasted in treating Shay from when he first time he arrived at Rotherham Hospital to before he was transferred to Sheffield Children's Hospital.

"I have to know whether the amount of insulin caused or contributed to his death, which I believe it did. He was in a compromised position and therefore was less likely to cope with the overdose.

(Image: SWNS)

"I feel incredibly letdown by the hospital by the manner in which they treated my son.

"The family have been left devastated, destroyed, heartbroken by the loss of Shay.

"We relive every moment of his death and it's left a huge void in our hearts. The amount of joy, love and laughter he brought us in five years is immeasurable.

"Now we are living in a nightmare we will never wake from. We are a shadow of our former selves."

(Image: SWNS)

Shay was transferred to Sheffield Children's Hospital in March last year but his condition deteriorated rapidly.

His stomach became swollen and, after he underwent surgery to remove his bowels, a CT scan showed he had suffered the brain injury.

Laura and husband Martyn, 29, a gas engineer, sat beside their 'happy” boy and turned the machines off on April 3 – four days after he was first admitted.

Shay's autopsy report said he died from multiple organ failure from an unknown cause leading to a bowel infection and causing sepsis.

Giving evidence, consultant forensic neuropathologist Dr Daniel du Plessis said Shay's brain injury was caused by a lack of blood and oxygen supply after admission to hospital but ruled out trauma.

The neuropathologist told an inquest that it was “highly unlikely” that Shay's brain damage was caused by the insulin over-dosage.

(Image: SWNS)

Dr du Plessis said it was difficult to pinpoint when the youngster's hypoxic brain injury developed but admitted that multiple organ failure “contributed substantially”.

He said: “I have no doubt that there was an excess of insulin given but it would appear that it was not long enough and severe enough to cause significant brain damage.

“There was no evidence the brain damage was a result of an over-dosage of insulin.”

(Image: SWNS)

Giving evidence, forensic pathologist Charles Wilson described the insulin over-dosage as a “red herring” and there was no evidence it significantly contributed to Shay's death.

Mr Wilson initially said Shay died from multiple organ failure due to shock from an unknown causation.

But after being asked again by the coroner, Mr Wilson said he could not argue that sepsis was the possible cause of the organ failure and that he would be happy to change the cause of death.

An inquest, which is likely to last five days, continues.
description: Shay Turner suffered a catastrophic brain injury after doctors at Rotherham General Hospital misdiagnosed him as a Type 1 diabetic
